Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story: I stood in the corner of the bustling hotel lounge, my habit drawing curious glances, my briefcase marking me as something else entirely. The clock on my phone blinked 6:55 a.m.—five minutes until morning prayers. Sister Agnes would expect me in the chapel, kneeling in silent devotion with the others. But here, at this networking breakfast, I was a lawyer first, expected to mingle, to build connections for the firm. A partner’s friend approached, coffee in hand, and with a friendly smile asked, “So, what kind of cases are you working on these days?” My mind raced. As a lawyer, I must protect my client’s confidentiality, never revealing details, not even in passing. As a nun, I am called to honesty and openness, to never deceive. The chapel bell echoed faintly through the city noise, a reminder of my other world. I felt the weight of both habits—the black veil and the tailored suit—pressing on my shoulders. My lips parted, but I hesitated, torn between the demands of my profession and my faith, between the expectations of those around me and the silent call within.
